children.text:
Thus, in Fortran, the code should be:

program codeforces_705_B
    implicit none
    integer :: t, i, prevWinner
    integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: arr
    
    read(*,*) t
    allocate( arr(t) ) read(*,*) (arr(i), i=1, t)
    
    prevWinner = 0 
    ! process each element do i = 1, t
        if( arr(i) == 1 .and. prevWinner ==0 ) then 
            prevWinner =2
        end if 

        ! now determine the output
        if( prevWinner ==2 .or. prevWinner ==0 ) then
            if( mod( arr(i) -1, 2 ) ==0 ) then 
                print *,2 
                prevWinner =2 
            else 
                print *,1 
                prevWinner =1 
            end if 
        else 
            if( mod( arr(i)-1, 2 ) ==0 ) then 
                print *,1 
                prevWinner=1 
            else 
                print *,2 
                prevWinner=2
            end
children.label: language_mapping

        end if 
    end do 

    deallocate(arr)
end program codeforces_705_B

program codeforces_705_B
    implicit none
    integer :: t, i, prevWinner
    integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: arr
    
    read(*,*) t
    allocate( arr(t) ) read(*,*) (arr(i), i = 1, t)
    
    prevWinner =0
    
    do i =1, t
        if( arr(i)==1 .and. prevWinner ==0 ) then
            prevWinner =2
        end if
        
        if ( prevWinner ==2 .or. prevWinner ==0 ) then
            if ( mod( arr(i) - 1, 2 ) ==0 ) then
                print *, 2
                prevWinner =2
            else
                print *,1 
                prevWinner =1
            end if
        else
            if ( mod( arr(i) -1,2 ) ==0 ) then 
                print *,1
                prevWinner =1
            else
                print *,2 
                prevWinner =2
            end if
        end if
    end do
    
    deallocate(arr)
    
end program codeforces_705_B

That seems correct. Wait but check the first condition:

In the Java code, the arr is indexed from 0 to t-1, but in Fortran it's 1 to t. The loop and code should correctly handle all elements.

Else (if prevWinner was 1?), then opposite.

But if the input is the first line the t and the second line the elements, no problem. Let me think about the code:

The Java code reads the input as follows: 

In solve() method:

The first nextInt() is t (number of elements, which is read as an integer here).

Then, loops to read each of the next t numbers, storing in the array. 

Thus, in Fortran, the code should be:

program codeforces_705_B
    implicit none
    integer :: t, i, prevWinner
    integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: arr
    
    read(*,*) t
    allocate( arr(t) ) 
    read(*,*) (arr(i), i=1, t)
    
    prevWinner = 0 
    ! process each element
    do i = 1, t
        if( arr(i) == 1 .and. prevWinner ==0 ) then 
            prevWinner =2
        end if 

        ! now determine the output
        if( prevWinner ==2 .or. prevWinner ==0 ) then
            if( mod( arr(i) -1, 2 ) ==0 ) then 
                print *,2 
                prevWinner =2 
            else 
                print *,1 
                prevWinner =1 
            end if 
        else 
            if( mod( arr(i)-1, 2 ) ==0 ) then 
                print *,1 
                prevWinner=1 
            else 
                print *,2 
                prevWinner=2
            end if 
        end if 
    end do 

    deallocate(arr)
end program codeforces_705_B 

Wait, but do we need to deallocate? Well, in Fortran, it's better to deallocate for arrays. But in code submission on Codeforces, it's probably not necessary, but better to include for correctness.

Wait the problem requires for each number in the array, to print the outcome (1 or 2), each on a new line. Let me see:

The Java code's System.out.println(2 or 1) means each result is on a new line. So the Fortran code's print *, number will also output each on a new line.

Another point: All variables should be declared in the program. prevWinner is initialized as 0. 

Yes, so in the code, prevWinner is initialized to 0.

Wait in the code:

prevWinner =0 

Yes.

So the complete code:

program codeforces_705_B
    implicit none
    integer :: t, i, prevWinner
    integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: arr
    
    read(*,*) t
    allocate( arr(t) )
    read(*,*) (arr(i), i = 1, t)
    
    prevWinner =0
    
    do i =1, t
        if( arr(i)==1 .and. prevWinner ==0 ) then
            prevWinner =2
        end if
        
        if ( prevWinner ==2 .or. prevWinner ==0 ) then
            if ( mod( arr(i) - 1, 2 ) ==0 ) then
                print *, 2
                prevWinner =2
            else
                print *,1 
                prevWinner =1
            end if
        else
            if ( mod( arr(i) -1,2 ) ==0 ) then 
                print *,1
                prevWinner =1
            else
                print *,2 
                prevWinner =2
            end if
        end if
    end do
    
    deallocate(arr)
    
end program codeforces_705_B
